text: in Winchester Massachusetts a quiet
suburb 30 minutes north of Boston a
handful of students are learning that
sometimes fighting is the answer for
three years a small but very dedicated
group of young men have spent their
afternoons in the Winchester high school
mixed martial arts Club learning the
basics of MMA which are jujitsu karate
Taekwondo and boxing there's a
misconception where people view mixed
martial artists as brawlers you know
guys would like to go out and start
fights and that's not what it is at all
not so long ago starting a martial arts
program at a high school would have been
next to impossible early marketing of
events like the ultimate fighting
championship put a heavy emphasis on
violence at one point the sport was
banned in 36 states and it wasn't until
2002 when safety rules were introduced
that sanction matches happened across
the country the MMA club has thrived in
one prays at Winchester high school
thanks to the tireless efforts of
angakok martial arts has always been
focus of my life and so in eighth grade
moving into high school I was
apprehensive about what sport I was to
do and I thought about perhaps football
maybe maybe wrestling but then I thought
why not martial arts since his sophomore
year of high school two years ago mr.
Quoc has been the club's organizer
fundraiser and ambassador he's
passionate but his pitch is a soft one
you know I could say oh yeah you know
you're gonna build a lot of confidence
you're in a bill discipline blah blah
but but you know I feel like a sales
person when I do that you just have to
come up and try for yourself see what
what it is and come they have many of
them refugees from other sports my name
is Brendan Cleary
a senior at Winchester high school I've
been doing this program for the past
year because i was doing football and
other sports i couldn't come up all the
time I'm a wrestler and I'm a martial
artist at heart like I never really
wanted to do other sports but just kind
of happened that way today young men
like Robert Flint a graduate of
Winchester high can come back to their
alma mater and teach a new generation of
kids the sport they never had a chance
to practice at school
when I was coming up through the school
I didn't have any opportunities like
this I didn't really fit into any of the
traditional sports teams and it was
tough you know but I feel like I'm
giving something back to the students
here that they can enjoy that I also
love to do I absolutely love to teach
and they're a great group of kids and
it's not just alums who come to help out
mr. Quoc regularly books world class
fighters and instructors like Marcelo
siquiera to teach his class on this fall
afternoon mr. siquiera a black belt in
Brazilian jiu-jitsu teaches technique
what they take out of it is control the
self-discipline they don't need to go
outside and fight or so on because did
they know they're better than that I
mean again you don't go learn football
to hit people to tackle people you don't
learn baseball to hit people with a
stick it's the same thing with martial
arts you don't learn martial art to go
outside and fight with other people the
sort was like basically what picked me
up back into athletics college would be
pretty hard for me to reach without the
discipline that Marshall has taught me
so it's really really changed my life if
this program hadn't started in this
hadn't gotten you know taking route I
probably would still be playing football
